item.title: Ex-Dallas cop cleared of murder allegation sues detective
item.author: Ken Miller - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Ex-Dallas cop cleared of murder allegation sues detective
media:content.media:description: Former Dallas police officer Bryan Riser sits for an examining trial in the County Criminal Court 3 at the Frank Crowley Courts Building on Wednesday, April 7, 2021, in Dallas. Riser A fired Dallas police officer who was cleared of ordering two killings in 2017 is now suing the detective who secured his arrest warrant. Riser is seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages, attorney fees and court costs from Det. Esteban Montenegro in the civil rights lawsuit filed Thursday, May 5, 2022 in U.S. District Court in Dallas. (Lynda M.
media:content.media:credit: The Dallas Morning News via AP

media:content.media:title: Ex-Dallas cop cleared of murder allegation sues detective
media:content.media:description: Homicide Detective Esteban Montenegro, right, answers questions for the prosecutor in the examination trial for former Dallas police officer Bryan Riser at the Frank Crowley Courts Building on Wednesday, April 7, 2021, in Dallas. Former Officer Bryan Riser is seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages, attorney fees and court costs from Det. Esteban Montenegro in the civil rights lawsuit filed Thursday, May 5, 2022, in U.S. District Court in Dallas. (Lynda M.
media:content.media:credit: The Dallas Morning News via AP

item.title: Police in Michigan chase shopper, shoot him in parking lot
item.author: The Associated Press

item.title: Liam and Olivia once again dominate top baby names list
item.author: Fatima Hussein - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Liam and Olivia once again dominate top baby names list
media:content.media:description: The toes of a baby are seen DHR Health, July 29, 2020, in McAllen, Texas. Olivia and Liam are once again America’s most common baby names. And Theodore joins the top 10 baby names list for the first time. The Social Security Administration annually tracks the names given to girls and boys in each state, with names dating back to 1880. The data is based on applications for Social Security cards.

item.title: Fire-ravaged New Mexico villages cling to faith, ‘querencia’
item.author: Felicia Fonseca - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Fire-ravaged New Mexico villages cling to faith, ‘querencia’
media:content.media:description: This May 4, 2022 image courtesy of Laura Paskus shows the silhouette of a cross amid smokey skies where hundreds of firefighters are battling a massive wildfire burning in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains near the community of Las Vegas, New Mexico.

item.title: Judge: Marjorie Taylor Greene is qualified for reelection
item.author: Kate Brumback - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Judge: Marjorie Taylor Greene is qualified for reelection
media:content.media:description: U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene prepares to testify, Friday, April 22, 2022, in Atlanta. Greene is appearing at a hearing Friday in Atlanta in a challenge filed by voters who say she shouldn't be allowed to seek reelection because she helped facilitate the attack on the Capitol that disrupted certification of Joe Biden's presidential victory.

media:content.media:title: Judge: Marjorie Taylor Greene is qualified for reelection
media:content.media:description: U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene speaks, Friday, April 22, 2022, in Atlanta. Greene is appearing at a hearing Friday in Atlanta in a challenge filed by voters who say she shouldn't be allowed to seek reelection because she helped facilitate the attack on the Capitol that disrupted certification of Joe Biden's presidential victory.

media:content.media:title: Judge: Marjorie Taylor Greene is qualified for reelection
media:content.media:description: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., speaks about Twitter, Thursday, April 28, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington.

item.title: Tenn. governor signs bill regulating medication abortions
item.author: Kimberlee Kruesi - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Tenn. governor signs bill regulating medication abortions
media:content.media:description: Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee delivers his State of the State address in the House Chamber of the Capitol building, Monday, Jan. 31, 2022, in Nashville, Tenn. Lee has signed legislation that will strictly regulate the dispensing of abortion pills, including imposing harsh penalties on doctors who violate them. The measure will go into effect Jan. 1, 2023.

item.title: Sri Lanka leader declares emergency amid protests
item.author: Krishan Francis And Eranga Jayawardena - The Associated Press
item.description: Sri Lanka’s president declared a state of emergency on Friday amid widespread public protests demanding his resignation over the country’s worst economic crisis recent memory.

media:content.media:title: Sri Lanka leader declares emergency amid protests
media:content.media:description: A Buddhist monk looks on a police use tear gas and a water canon to disperse university students protesting to demand the resignation of Sri Lanka's President Gotabaya Rajapaksa over the country's crippling economic crisis, near the parliament building in Colombo on May 6, 2022.

item.title: Protective order against lieutenant gov candidate tossed
item.author: Michael Rubinkam - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Protective order against lieutenant gov candidate tossed
media:content.media:description: Republican candidate for Pennsylvania lieutenant governor Teddy Daniels reacts outside the Wayne County Court House in Honesdale, Pa. on Friday, May 6, 2022. Daniels appeared in court on accusations made by his wife that he had been persistently verbally abusive, stalking her at work and keeping her away from family.

media:content.media:title: Protective order against lieutenant gov candidate tossed
media:content.media:description: Republican candidate for Pennsylvania lieutenant governor Teddy Daniels departs from the Wayne County Court House in Honesdale, Pa. on Friday, May 6, 2022. Daniels appeared in court on accusations made by his wife that he had been persistently verbally abusive, stalking her at work and keeping her away from family.

media:content.media:title: Protective order against lieutenant gov candidate tossed

media:content.media:title: Protective order against lieutenant gov candidate tossed
media:content.media:description: Republican candidate for Pennsylvania lieutenant governor Teddy Daniels speaks to the media outside the Wayne County Court House in Honesdale, Pa. on Friday, May 6, 2022. Daniels appeared in court on accusations made by his wife that he had been persistently verbally abusive, stalking her at work and keeping her away from family.

media:content.media:description: Republican candidate for Pennsylvania lieutenant governor Teddy Daniels speaks to the media outside the Wayne County Court House in Honesdale, Pa. on Friday, May 6, 2022. media:content.media:description: Teddy Daniels, a Republican candidate for Pennsylvania lieutenant governor, enters the Wayne County Courthouse in Honesdale, Pa., on Friday, May 6, 2022, for a hearing on a protection from abuse order.
